checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
This is a library to program and train graph neural networks. The proposal mentions training GNNs as an objective. Aligns with the approved research topic Datascience and engineering. 
KSL will provide the Pyg container image from NVIDIA and update with required software.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
FAIR Chemistry License v1 ( a custom license by Meta).
Permissions:

Use - Use the Materials (models, code, weights, documentation)

Reproduce - Copy the Materials

Distribute - Share the Materials with third parties

Modify - Make modifications to the Materials

Create Derivative Works - Build upon the Materials

Commercial Use - License is royalty-free (no payment required)

Worldwide - License applies globally

Own Derivatives - You own derivative works and modifications you create

Publish Research - Can publish research results using the Materials

Restrictions:

Non-Transferable - License cannot be transferred to others

Acceptable Use Policy Compliance - Must follow prohibited use restrictions (military, nuclear, weapons, ITAR, espionage, etc.)

Geographic Restrictions - Not available in comprehensively sanctioned jurisdictions, China, Russia, and Belarus

Termination on Litigation - License terminates if you sue Meta over the Materials

Indemnification - Must hold Meta harmless from third-party claims arising from your use

checks.name: Training Data Documentation
checks.notes:
Primary Training Datasets
1. OC20 (Open Catalyst 2020)

1,281,040 DFT relaxations (~264,890,000 single-point evaluations)
Covers wide range of materials, surfaces, and adsorbates (nitrogen, carbon, oxygen chemistries)
Purpose: Catalyst discovery for renewable energy applications
Source: Meta AI / Open Catalyst Project
Estimated JSON tokens: 1.8T


2. OC22 (Open Catalyst 2022)

Extension focusing on oxide materials
Used to demonstrate data efficiency vs. GemNet-OC
Source: Meta AI / Open Catalyst Project
Comparison/Ablation Dataset
Estimated JSON tokens: 89B

3. QM9

Used for comparison with original Equiformer
Standard benchmark for molecular property prediction
~134K small organic molecules with quantum chemical properties
Estimated JSON tokens: negligible

checks.name: Customisation / Fine-tuning
checks.notes: No fine-tuning for downstream tasks are available.

checks.name: FLOPS Calculation
checks.notes:
EquiformerV2-L (Large) has 153 x 10^6 parameters. 

pretraining dataset tokens estimate is : 89 x 10^9 + 1.8 x 10^12 ~ 1.889 x 10^12
Therefore pre-trained model will have:
 
6 x 153 x 10^6 x 1.889 x 10^12 = 1.734 x 10^21

1.734 x 10^21 is orders of magnitude less than 10^27, therefore below threshold.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: low risk, no inspection conducted.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes: JMP (Joint Multi-domain Pre-training) is a supervised pre-training strategy for atomistic/chemical ML that learns transferable representations for atomic property prediction by multi-task training across multiple chemistry/materials datasets. In the proposal, JMP/UMA is referenced as prior supervised foundation-model work and is used mainly as a baseline/point of comparison for the proposal’s objective of rigorously comparing supervised vs self-supervised pretraining for materials foundation models.

checks.name: Customisation / Fine-tuning
checks.notes: The paper/repo describe fine-tuning/evaluation across benchmarks including QM9, rMD17, MatBench, QMOF, SPICE, and MD22 (spanning small molecules, large molecules, and materials).

checks.name: FLOPS Calculation
checks.notes:
The JMP work reports scaling up to a model with ~235M trainable parameters (parameter count depends on the specific checkpoint/config). 

Pretraining dataset tokens estimate is : 89 x 10^9 + 1.8 x 10^12 ~ 1.889 x 10^12
Therefore pre-trained model will have:
 
6 x 153 x 10^6 x 1.889 x 10^12 = 1.734 x 10^21

1.734 x 10^21 is orders of magnitude less than 10^27, therefore below threshold.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: Low risk. Skipping inspection.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
UMA (Universal Models for Atoms) is a family of large equivariant interatomic-potential models that predicts DFT-like energies/forces (and related properties) for atomistic structures across molecules, materials, and catalysts, aiming for strong zero-shot generalization. 
In the proposal, UMA is used as a state-of-the-art MLIP/backbone reference point and as a target architecture to which the project will apply self-supervised generative pretraining (AR/flow-matching/diffusion) and compare against supervised pretraining at scale. 

Aligns with the approved research topic of Data Science and engineering.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation classified in Prohibited Use Screening in accordance with LC 2.7.

checks.name: Source / Provenance & D5+M Affiliation Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
UMA is authored and released by FAIR at Meta with collaborators from Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), and the official usage/docs are hosted under the FAIRChem ecosystem.

HF Model: https://huggingface.co/facebook/UMA 
Downloads are not tracked for this model

LinkedIn (found):
Brandon M. Wood (Meta FAIR)
Misko Dzamba (Meta) - https://www.linkedin.com/in/misko-dzamba-508091a7 - USA
Anuroop Sriram (Meta FAIR) - https://www.linkedin.com/in/anuroopsriram/ - USA

Non-D5

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes: Models are made accessible for commerical and non-commerical use under a permissive license found in https://huggingface.co/facebook/UMA/blob/main/LICENSE

checks.name: Training Data Documentation
checks.notes:
UMA models are trained on ~0.5 billion unique 3D atomic structures, compiled across multiple chemistry domains (molecules/materials/catalysts) and multiple datasets/DFT settings . The Open Molecules 2025 (OMol25) and Open
Materials 2024 (OMat24). . In combination, these datasets contain close to 500 million training examples with over 30 billion atoms

checks.name: Customisation / Fine-tuning
checks.notes: UMA is evaluated across many domains and, where needed for consistent DFT settings on specific public benchmarks, the paper describes fine-tuning for materials evaluations (e.g., using MPTrj and sAlex).

checks.name: FLOPS Calculation
checks.notes:
The paper reports multiple UMA sizes, including UMA-S ~150M total params, UMA-M ~1.4B total params (~50M “active” per structure via MoLE), and UMA-L ~700M params.
Considering 1.4B as trainable parameters.

Pretraining dataset tokens estimate is : 89 x 10^9 + 1.8 x 10^12 ~ 1.889 x 10^12
Therefore pre-trained model will have:
 
6 x 153 x 10^6 x 1.889 x 10^12 = 1.734 x 10^21

1.734 x 10^21 is orders of magnitude less than 10^27, therefore below threshold.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: No risk in LC2.7 check, skipping inspection.

observations:
In the Open Catalyst dataset, a potential risk of dual use has been identified. A suggestion is to refer to the RCAC Chair for the scientific assessment of potential risk. 
In the Open Materials dataset, a potential risk of dual use has been identified. A suggestion is to refer to the RCAC Chair for the scientific assessment of potential risk. 
In the Open Molecules 2025  dataset, the artifact is new and less used.

In GemNet model, a potential risk of dual use has been identified. A suggestion is to refer to the RCAC Chair for the scientific assessment of potential risk.
recommendation:
Positive check passed. 

Negative check passed with potential risk identified. 

10^27 check passed. 

The initial recommendation is to refer to RCAC for the scientific assessment of potential risks found in said datasets and model. Conditional on clearance from the RCAC, the project is otherwise recommended for the grand challenge.
